title: Exponential function
text:
The exponential function is a mathematical <a href="Function%20%28mathematics%29">function</a> denoted by formula_1 or formula_2 (where the argument is written as an <a href="exponentiation">exponent</a>). It can be defined in <a href="Characterizations%20of%20the%20exponential%20function">several equivalent ways</a>. Its ubiquitous occurrence in <a href="Pure%20mathematics">pure</a> and <a href="applied%20mathematics">applied mathematics</a> led mathematician <a href="Walter%20Rudin">Walter Rudin</a> to opine that the exponential function is "the most important function in mathematics". Its value at 1, formula_3 is a <a href="mathematical%20constant">mathematical constant</a> called <a href="e%20%28mathematical%20constant%29">Euler's number</a>.
The exponential function equals its own <a href="derivative">derivative</a>. Thus, it appears in the solutions of many <a href="differential%20equations">differential equations</a>.
Moreover, it satisfies the <a href="identity%20%28mathematics%29">identity</a> 
which, along with the definition formula_5, shows that formula_6 for positive integers , relating the exponential function to the elementary notion of <a href="exponentiation">exponentiation</a>.
The argument of the exponential function can be any <a href="Real%20number">real</a> or <a href="complex%20number">complex number</a>. This allows one to extend the concept of <a href="exponentiation">exponentiation</a> (which would normally be defined only for integer exponents as: formula_7 for integer ) to <a href="Real%20number">real</a> or <a href="Complex%20number">complex</a> <a href="exponents">exponents</a>, by defining formula_8 for positive and real or complex . The exponential of a <a href="complex%20number">complex</a> argument is closely related to <a href="trigonometry">trigonometry</a> as shown by <a href="Euler%27s%20formula">Euler's formula</a>. The argument can even be an entirely different kind of <a href="mathematical%20object">mathematical object</a> (for example, a <a href="square%20matrix">square matrix</a>).
In applied settings, exponential functions model a relationship in which a constant change in the independent variable gives the same proportional change (that is, percentage increase or decrease) in the dependent variable. This occurs widely in the natural and social sciences, as in a self-reproducing <a href="Population%20dynamics">population</a>, a fund accruing compound <a href="interest">interest</a>, or a <a href="Moore%27s%20law">growing body of manufacturing expertise</a>. Thus, the exponential function also appears in a variety of contexts within <a href="physics">physics</a>, <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a>, <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="engineering">engineering</a>, <a href="mathematical%20biology">mathematical biology</a>, and <a href="economics">economics</a>. 
The real exponential function is a <a href="bijection">bijection</a> from formula_9 to formula_10. Its <a href="inverse%20function">inverse function</a> is the <a href="natural%20logarithm">natural logarithm</a>, denoted formula_11 formula_12 or formula_13 because of this, some old texts refer to the exponential function as the antilogarithm.
"The" exponential function is sometimes called the natural exponential function for distinguishing it from the other "exponential functions", which are the functions of the form formula_14 where the base is a positive <a href="real%20number">real number</a>. The definition formula_15 for positive and <a href="real%20number">real</a> or <a href="complex%20number">complex</a> establishes a strong relationship between these functions, which explains this ambiguous terminology.

Overview.
The exponential function arises whenever a quantity <a href="exponential%20growth">grows</a> or <a href="exponential%20decay">decays</a> at a rate <a href="Proportionality%20%28mathematics%29">proportional</a> to its current value. One such situation is <a href="continuously%20compounded%20interest">continuously compounded interest</a>, and in fact it was this observation that led <a href="Jacob%20Bernoulli">Jacob Bernoulli</a> in 1683 to the number
now known as . Later, in 1697, <a href="Johann%20Bernoulli">Johann Bernoulli</a> studied the calculus of the exponential function.
If a principal amount of 1 earns interest at an annual rate of compounded monthly, then the interest earned each month is times the current value, so each month the total value is multiplied by , and the value at the end of the year is . If instead interest is compounded daily, this becomes . Letting the number of time intervals per year grow without bound leads to the <a href="limit%20of%20a%20function">limit</a> definition of the exponential function,
first given by <a href="Leonhard%20Euler">Leonhard Euler</a>.
This is one of a number of <a href="characterizations%20of%20the%20exponential%20function">characterizations of the exponential function</a>; others involve <a href="series%20%28mathematics%29">series</a> or <a href="differential%20equation">differential equation</a>s.
From any of these definitions it can be shown that the exponential function obeys the basic <a href="exponentiation">exponentiation</a> identity,
which justifies the notation for .
The <a href="derivative">derivative</a> (rate of change) of the exponential function is the exponential function itself. More generally, a function with a rate of change "proportional" to the function itself (rather than equal to it) is expressible in terms of the exponential function. This function property leads to <a href="exponential%20growth">exponential growth</a> or <a href="exponential%20decay">exponential decay</a>.
The exponential function extends to an <a href="entire%20function">entire function</a> on the <a href="complex%20plane">complex plane</a>. <a href="Euler%27s%20formula">Euler's formula</a> relates its values at purely imaginary arguments to <a href="trigonometric%20functions">trigonometric functions</a>. The exponential function also has analogues for which the argument is a <a href="matrix%20exponential">matrix</a>, or even an element of a <a href="Banach%20algebra">Banach algebra</a> or a <a href="Lie%20algebra">Lie algebra</a>.

See <a href="Exponentiation%23Failure%20of%20power%20and%20logarithm%20identities">failure of power and logarithm identities</a> for more about problems with combining powers.
The exponential function maps any <a href="line%20%28mathematics%29">line</a> in the complex plane to a <a href="logarithmic%20spiral">logarithmic spiral</a> in the complex plane with the center at the <a href="Origin%20%28mathematics%29">origin</a>. Two special cases exist: when the original line is parallel to the real axis, the resulting spiral never closes in on itself; when the original line is parallel to the imaginary axis, the resulting spiral is a circle of some radius.

Lie algebras.
Given a <a href="Lie%20group">Lie group</a> and its associated <a href="Lie%20algebra">Lie algebra</a> formula_100, the <a href="exponential%20map%20%28Lie%20theory%29">exponential map</a> is a map formula_100 satisfying similar properties. In fact, since is the Lie algebra of the Lie group of all positive real numbers under multiplication, the ordinary exponential function for real arguments is a special case of the Lie algebra situation. Similarly, since the Lie group of invertible matrices has as Lie algebra , the space of all matrices, the exponential function for square matrices is a special case of the Lie algebra exponential map.
The identity can fail for Lie algebra elements and that do not commute; the <a href="Baker%E2%80%93Campbell%E2%80%93Hausdorff%20formula">Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff formula</a> supplies the necessary correction terms.

Computation.
When computing (an approximation of) the exponential function near the argument , the result will be close to 1, and computing the value of the difference formula_102 with <a href="floating-point%20arithmetic">floating-point arithmetic</a> may lead to the loss of (possibly all) <a href="significant%20figures">significant figures</a>, producing a large calculation error, possibly even a meaningless result.
